title: EEGLabGuideRepro
text:
This document is a guide on how to use the EEG lab for a testing session. Depending on your specific study, some steps might be added or modified. Neverthelss, this guide is the basis for a clean and smooth testing procedure. All rules should be respected, unless the primary investigator for your study tells you otherwise.






WARNING



As the EEG equipment is very expensive and some parts of the equipment are also fragile, the entire procedure should be done with great carethis document should be read carefully.


For any questions or in case of unexpected incidents, please reach out to the following people:

Alexa Ruel (alexa.ruel@uni-hamburg.de ; office VMP5, Room 4077)
Marit Petzka (marit.petzka@uni-hamburg.de)
Nicolas Schuck (nicolas.schuck@uni-hamburg.de)

title: 2  Hardware Components
text:
The EEG lab room is comprised (1) the EEG cabin (2) the workstation and (3) the cleaning station.
The task is performed inside the cabin, while the computers outside the cabin at the workstation runs the task and data collection. The workstation also includes the cleaning equipment, syringes, paper tissues, and towels.









The EEG Cabin







The Workstation







The Cleaning Station





Outside the EEG cabin, at the workstation, you find see the task laptop, the EEG tower, and the trigger box. The laptop executes the experiment task and collects behavioral data, the tower records the EEG data, and the trigger box integrates triggers with the EEG data.









EEG Tower







Battery







Trigger Box





Inside the EEG cabin, you will find the amplifier, battery, participant’s monitor, and electrode cap and cable to carry out the experiment. The electrodes are connected to the amplifier which is powered by the battery. The monitor displays the task for the participant, and the cap provides a base for the electrodes to collect the data.









Electrodes cap







Participant’s Monitor







Amplifier





The cleaning station is where you will find:









Syringes







Gel







Towels & Shampoo





Do not forget to turn on the ventilator:









Ventilator







Ventilator set on 2

title: 3  Before Testing
text:
3.1 Prepare Battery
Step 1: Connect the green male wire (notch aligned) to green port on the battery.
Step 2: Do the same for the red wire and port on amplifier.

title: 3  Before Testing
text:
REMINDER



The battery must stay pluged in all the time when not in use.











On the Battery







On the Amplifier







Battery and Amplifier Connected

title: 3  Before Testing
text:
3.2 Turn on Participant Cabin Monitor
Power button is a small, hard-to-find front-bottom right button (not on back).









Power Button

title: 3  Before Testing
section: 3.3 Power on the Task Laptop and EEG Tower
text:
3.3 Power on the Task Laptop and EEG Tower
Step 1: Log into the Admin account on the EEG Tower and task laptop (password: 4073abc).
Step 2: On the Tower: Launch BrainVision Recorder (click “Yes” when prompted).
Step 3: When the program is open, you should see a gray screen.









luvadmin Account







Click Yes







Grey Screen on BrainVision

title: 3  Before Testing
text:
3.4 Prepare EEG Gel Syringes
The syringes are stored under the sink inside boxes.
The gel tub, tips box, Q-tips, scissors, and tissues are kept on the shelf next to the sink.









Boxes of Syringes







Gel tub, Tips box, Q-tips, Scissors & Tissues





Step 1: Take out the syringes and the tips from their packaging.
Step 2: Fill two syringes with gel.
Step 3: Close the gel tub immediately to prevent drying.
Step 4: Attach the tips to the filled syringes.
Step 5: Cut one of the Q-tips ends with the scissors.
Step 6: Place two tissues and two Q-tips on the cabin bed in preparation for the participant.









Step 1







Step 2







Step 3









Step 4







Step 5







Step 6

title: 4  Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
4.1 Head Measurement
Step 1: Measure around the head like a baseball cap (~1.5 - 2 cm / ~½–1 inch above eyebrows).
Step 2: If between sizes (e.g., 57), start smaller (e.g., 56) and go up if the cap is too tight.

title: 4  Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
Available Cap Sizes:



54, 56, 58, 60











Correct Way of Head Measurement









Cap Size

title: 4  Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
4.2 Putting on the Cap
Step 1: Ask participant to hold the back tag to help you get the cap on their head. Step 2: Pull cap on from back to front. Step 3: Ask them to keep their head up straight and steady. Step 4: Place your hand on the top of their head. Step 5: Slide the cap until it gets roughly to the right position. Step 6: Ask them to identify their occipital bone bump (back of head).









Prticipant Holding the Tag







Sliding the Cap







Occipital Bone Bump

title: 4  Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
4.3 Check Reference Location
Step 1: Measure from the spot between eyebrows to the occipital bump.
Step 2: Measure from ear to ear. The reference electrode should be approximately midpoint between eyebrows and occipital bone as well as midpoint between the ears (ok if slightly off).
Note: This should result in the ground electrode being slightly above the eyebrows, but below the mid-forehead.
Step 3: Adjust cap again as described above if needed.










Step 1







Step 2







Checking the Reference Location

title: 4  Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
4.4 Chin Strap
Step 1: Ask participant to fasten chin strap themselves.

title: 4  Cap & Electrode Preparation
text:
4.5 Plugging in the Electrodes
Step 1: Match Electrode Band 1–32 and 33–64 to the amplifier. Step 2: Use arrow on plug (top right) to align with amplifier port. Step 3: Insert straight in — do not bend, force, or wiggle. Step 4: Plug GND (ground electrode) separately into port labeled “GND” (round plug).









Match Electrode Bands with Amplifier







Insert Straight in









Both Bands Plugged in







Plug in the Ground

title: 5  Gel Demonstration & Impedance Setup
text:
5.1 Start Impedance Check
Step 1: On EEG Tower, hit Impedance button (2nd top-left in BrainVision). Electrodes will light up red.

title: 5  Gel Demonstration & Impedance Setup
text: Impedance Check on BrainVision

title: 5  Gel Demonstration & Impedance Setup
text:
5.2 Gel Application Tips
Step 1: Angle syringe toward the electrode base. Step 2: Apply gel into each electrode until you see a small amount come out of the hole. Step 3: Swirl gel with the blunt end of the Q-tip (circular motion).









Apply Gel







Swirl with a Q-tip











IMPORTANT



Only when all electrodes are green (you have successfully reduced impendence to good level), proceed to the next step (recording).

title: 6  Starting the Recording
text:
6.1 On EEG Tower
Step 1: Hit Stop sign.
Step 2: Click the Eyeball icon.
Step 3: Hit the play button.
Step 4: Add your participants ID and other information on the file name.
Step 5: Save the file to start recording.
Step 6: Confirm that BrainVision is recording (green play button is active, time elapsed is at the bottom of the screen).

title: 6  Starting the Recording
text:
Check



The recording is indicated by a red bar on the bottom of the screen (“SAVING HDD”).

title: 6  Starting the Recording
text: 6.2 Images to be added

title: 7  Reminders & Breaks
text:
7.1 Remind them to:
1.1 Stay still between blocks 1.2 Let you know if they need a break 1.3 Knock on the cabin wall if they need help 1.4 Look at the fixation cross when it’s on the screen.

title: 7  Reminders & Breaks
text:
7.2 Bathroom Breaks (if needed)
Step 1: Pause recording in BrainVision






IMPORTANT



DON’T HIT THE STOP BUTTON.


Step 2: Clamp electrode bundles with clip or tie. Step 3: Walk participant to bathroom.

title: 7  Reminders & Breaks
text:
7.3 Upon return
Step 1: Re-run impedance check to quickly ensure the electrodes are getting good readings. Step 2: Restart recording (append data). Step 3: Continue task.

title: 8  After the Task
text:
8.1 Stop the Recording
Step 1: Stop BrainVision recording, by hitting the stop symbol.

title: 8  After the Task
text:
8.2 Cap and Electrode Removal Procedure
Step 1: Ask participant to remove chin strap.
Step 2: Remove cap by placing your fingers under the front of the cap and removing it front to back.
Step 3: Unplug the bands. (See below)






IMPORTANT



Wrap connector boxes in a towel. The connectors are very sensitive and must not be wet. Even small drops of water can damage them. Be especially careful to keep them dry.

title: 8  After the Task
text:
8.3 Unplug Bands
Step 1: Pinch base of plug and pull straight up.







IMPORTANT



Do not pull on the wire as you may damage the connection. You should only use the plastic connector.


Step 2: For the ground electrode (labeled as GND), pinch at the plastic/amp junction and pull directly out—note that this is difficult to do so requires some force.
This CANNOT be bent or it will damage the pins inside the plug connector. DO NOT PULL ON THE WIRE.









Pinch and Pull up







Ground Electrode Unplugging

title: 8  After the Task
text:
8.4 Post-Session Hair Cleaning Support
Step 1: Provide the time and materials for the participant to wash their hair (clean towel, shampoo, hairdryer, brush or comb). They can be found on the shelf to the left side of the cabinet under the sink.
Step 2: Close curtain for privacy



Clean towel, Shampoo, Hairdryer

title: 8  After the Task
text:
8.5 Charge the Battery
Step 1: Move the battery from the cabin to the experimenter desk outside the cabin, plug it in by aligning the notch in the cable to the slit in the hole on the battery. Push until you hear a click.






IMPORTANT



The battery must remain plugged in to charge at all times when not in use.





Battery Plugged in


Once participant is out of EEG lab and done washing their hair proceed to the next step.

title: 8  After the Task
text:
8.6 Electrode Cleaning
Step 1: Plug the sink and fill it with lukewarm/cold water and place them in the blue basket.






WARNING



Do not use warm water! This will damage the electrodes.


Step 2: Gently scrub gel out with a toothbrush until there is no more gel on the electrodes.
Step 3: Hang the electrodes on the hanger on the wall to the right side of the sink.






WARNING



The electrodes must not come in contact with any type of metal ever! This is very important to keep in mind at every single step of the experiment, especially while moving, washing and hanging the electrodes.


Step 4: Wash cap, hang to dry on plastic stand (left of sink). You can use the fan on the cap to dry it faster. This is necessary if you are testing more than one participant in the same day.
#IMAGES TO BE ADDED

title: 9  Final Cleanup
text:
10 Lab Closeout
Step 1: Shut down both computers.
Step 2: Ensure at least 2 clean towels are ready for the next day. If not, do laundry in Room 4135 (will need about 4.5 hours to complete).
Step 3: Lock all the doors.

title: 9  Final Cleanup
text:
10.1 Laundry Instructions

10.1.1 Siemens Washer/Dryer settings
Step 1: Put the laundry detergent in the left-hand compartment.
Step 2: Set the washing program on “Koch/Buntwasche”.
Step 3: 60 degrees.
Step 4: Choose quick cycle on the screen.
Step 5: Choose drying cycle to be the wardrobe.










Put the Laundry Detergent







Set the Washing Program









Set the Temparature







Choose the Drying Cycle

title: 10  BrainVision Workspace
text:
10.1 Pre-requisites
Workspace saves user defined settings. It also stores all the settings you make in the amplifier and configuration menus, the impedance measurement settings. You can set up multiple workspaces with different settings, and switch between these as you wish. This provides you with an easy way to access recording parameters that you use frequently.

title: 10  BrainVision Workspace
text:
An amplifier is selected

The amplifier is connected to the recording computer

title: 10  BrainVision Workspace
text:
10.2 How to Open/Create the Workspace (Wizards)
Step 1: Click on File > New Workspace… or File > Edit Workspace…
Step 2: Data File Settings : to set all file related options

title: 10  BrainVision Workspace
text:
10.3 Amplifier Settings
The second page contains amplifier-specific parameters (1) and the channel table (2).

title: 10  BrainVision Workspace
text:
10.4 Filter Settings
There are 3 Filter Methods:

Raw Data Saving Filters
Filters are directly applied to the raw data. Use of this filter is not recommended, because this changes the raw data. When using BrainVision Analyzer you can apply filters to the raw data.
Segmentation Filters
When you specify segmentation (subsequent tab of the workspace wizard) you can also set filters for the segmented data.
Display Filters
This filter only has an effect on the display on your screen. When you set the filter, you can switch it on and off during the data display by clicking on the Display Filter button.

title: 10  BrainVision Workspace
text:
10.5 Segmentation / Averaging
This dialog allows you to make optional settings for segmentation and averaging.

title: 10  BrainVision Workspace
text:
10.6 Saving
When you click on Finish, the Save As dialog opens allowing you to save the workspace file. Give the file a meaningful name and click Save.

title: 10  BrainVision Workspace
text:
10.7 Electrode Position Files (EPF)
Used to assign electrode names, positions, and physical channels in a workspace using predefined data from the cap manufacturer. It gives users the opportunity to adapt the electrode position data (for example, the physical channel). The EPF is written in XML format and is saved as a .BVEF file. This can be opened and edited in a text editor. The file has the following structure (see also the Analyzer Manual):

title: 10  BrainVision Workspace
text:
10.8 Create Workspace Using an EPF

10.8.1 Pre-requisites

An amplifier is selected

The amplifier is connected to the recording computer

Step 1: Click on File > New Workspace… or go to the Amplifier Settings dialog (second dialog page).
Step 2: Click on Use Electrode Position File.
Step 3: Select the checkbox Read positions from Electrode Position File.
Step 4: Click on Browse and locate the electrode position file (.BVEF). (If you want to check the file, click on Preview).
Step 5:* Click on Import amplifier channel table. Recorder takes over the assignment of channel names and physical channels.






Note



Don’t click this button if you edit an existing workspace and want to keep the channel assignment.


Step 6: Click on OK to load the electrode positions (topographies).
The electrode positions and the channel table (if applicable) are loaded into Recorder. The information is written into the header file. You can check the result in the impedance measurement window.






Note



Load complete files (covers the channel table and electrode topography): Steps 1–6








Note



Load electrode topography (only electrodes that are already present in the channel table): Skip Step 5
